segment.source: Deploy push-button reset features
segment.target: Deploy push-button reset features

segment.source: Deploy push-button reset features
segment.target: Deploy push-button reset features

segment.source: Push-button reset features are included with Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), though you'll need to perform additional steps to deploy PCs with the following customizations.
segment.target: Push-button reset features are included with Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), though you'll need to perform additional steps to deploy PCs with the following customizations.

segment.source: Classic Windows applications
segment.target: Classic Windows applications

segment.source: Windows settings, such as customized OOBE screens or Start Menus.
segment.target: Windows settings, such as customized OOBE screens or Start Menus.

segment.source: Customized partition layouts.
segment.target: Customized partition layouts.

segment.source: These steps also show you how to add your own scripts during a reset to capture logs or perform other cleanup tasks.
segment.target: These steps also show you how to add your own scripts during a reset to capture logs or perform other cleanup tasks.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: To complete these procedures, you'll need a technician PC which has Windows 10 and the following Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 components installed:
segment.target: To complete these procedures, you'll need a technician PC which has Windows 10 and the following Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 components installed:

segment.source: Deployment Tools
segment.target: Deployment Tools

segment.source: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)
segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)

segment.source: Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)
segment.target: Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)

segment.source: User State Migration Tool (USMT)
segment.target: User State Migration Tool (USMT)

segment.source: You'll also need:
segment.target: You'll also need:

segment.source: A destination PC with drive size of 100 GB or larger
segment.target: A destination PC with drive size of 100 GB or larger

segment.source: A Windows 10 for desktop editions image (install.wim)
segment.target: A Windows 10 for desktop editions image (install.wim)

segment.source: A Windows RE boot image (Winre.wim) (You'll extract this from a Windows 10 image).
segment.target: A Windows RE boot image (Winre.wim) (You'll extract this from a Windows 10 image).

segment.source: For an overview of the entire deployment process, see the Desktop manufacturing guide.
segment.target: For an overview of the entire deployment process, see the Desktop manufacturing guide.

segment.source: Use the follow steps to prepare the ScanState tool to capture Classic Windows applications after they have been installed:
segment.target: Use the follow steps to prepare the ScanState tool to capture Classic Windows applications after they have been installed:

segment.source: Step 1: Prepare the ScanState tool
segment.target: Step 1: Prepare the ScanState tool

segment.source: On the technician PC, copy the Windows ADK files from Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT) and Windows Setup to a working folder.
segment.target: On the technician PC, copy the Windows ADK files from Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT) and Windows Setup to a working folder.

segment.source: You'll need to match the architecture of the destination device.
segment.target: You'll need to match the architecture of the destination device.

segment.source: You don't need to copy the subfolders.
segment.target: You don't need to copy the subfolders.

segment.source: In some instances, Windows Defender settings and detection history might be captured into the customizations package by the ScanState tool.
segment.target: In some instances, Windows Defender settings and detection history might be captured into the customizations package by the ScanState tool.

segment.source: This can lead to failures during recovery due to file conflicts, and causes the PC to reboot and enter the "Installing Windows" phase repeatedly.
segment.target: This can lead to failures during recovery due to file conflicts, and causes the PC to reboot and enter the "Installing Windows" phase repeatedly.

segment.source: These next steps will prevent the capture of Windows Defender settings.
segment.target: These next steps will prevent the capture of Windows Defender settings.

segment.source: Using the ScanState tool on a PC running Windows 10, generate a configuration file:
segment.target: Using the ScanState tool on a PC running Windows 10, generate a configuration file:

segment.source: Open the configuration file in notepad
segment.target: Open the configuration file in notepad

segment.source: Search for the following lines in the configuration file:
segment.target: Search for the following lines in the configuration file:

segment.source: Modify the "migrate" value from "yes" to "no" for each line.
segment.target: Modify the "migrate" value from "yes" to "no" for each line.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: In step 10 later in this topic, you will specify the configuration file when you use ScanState to capture the customizations into a .ppkg file.
segment.target: In step 10 later in this topic, you will specify the configuration file when you use ScanState to capture the customizations into a .ppkg file.

segment.source: Save and close the configuration file.
segment.target: Save and close the configuration file.

segment.source: Copy the contents of the working folder to a network location or USB flash drive.
segment.target: Copy the contents of the working folder to a network location or USB flash drive.

segment.source: Use the following steps to customize your Windows RE boot image if additional drivers and language packs are needed.
segment.target: Use the following steps to customize your Windows RE boot image if additional drivers and language packs are needed.

segment.source: Step 2: Extract and customize the Windows RE boot image (optional)
segment.target: Step 2: Extract and customize the Windows RE boot image (optional)

segment.source: On the technician PC, click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: On the technician PC, click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: In Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, create the folder structure to store the Windows image and its mount point.
segment.target: In Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, create the folder structure to store the Windows image and its mount point.

segment.source: Create the folder structure to store the Windows RE boot image and its mount point.
segment.target: Create the folder structure to store the Windows RE boot image and its mount point.

segment.source: Mount the Windows image (install.wim) to the folder OSimagemount by using DISM.
segment.target: Mount the Windows image (install.wim) to the folder OSimagemount by using DISM.

segment.source: where is the index of the selected image in the Install.wim file.
segment.target: where is the index of the selected image in the Install.wim file.

segment.source: Copy the Windows RE image from the mounted Windows image to the new folder.
segment.target: Copy the Windows RE image from the mounted Windows image to the new folder.

segment.source: Unmount the Windows image.
segment.target: Unmount the Windows image.

segment.source: Tip: If you haven't made any other changes in the Windows image, you can unmount the image faster by using the option.
segment.target: Tip: If you haven't made any other changes in the Windows image, you can unmount the image faster by using the option.

segment.source: Mount the Windows RE boot image for editing.
segment.target: Mount the Windows RE boot image for editing.

segment.source: where is the number of the selected image in the Winre.wim file.
segment.target: where is the number of the selected image in the Winre.wim file.

segment.source: Once the Winre.wim file is extracted from the Install.wim file, you can customize the Windows RE boot image.
segment.target: Once the Winre.wim file is extracted from the Install.wim file, you can customize the Windows RE boot image.

segment.source: Add language packs, boot-critical device drivers, and input device drivers to the Windows RE boot image.
segment.target: Add language packs, boot-critical device drivers, and input device drivers to the Windows RE boot image.

segment.source: To learn more, see Customize Windows RE.
segment.target: To learn more, see Customize Windows RE.

segment.source: Commit your customizations and unmount the image.
segment.target: Commit your customizations and unmount the image.

segment.source: If you are planning to customize only the settings common to all editions of Windows 10 (including Windows 10 Mobile), use the following steps to create a provisioning package which specifies settings to be restored during recovery:
segment.target: If you are planning to customize only the settings common to all editions of Windows 10 (including Windows 10 Mobile), use the following steps to create a provisioning package which specifies settings to be restored during recovery:

segment.source: Step 3: Create a provisioning package with settings to be restored (optional)
segment.target: Step 3: Create a provisioning package with settings to be restored (optional)

segment.source: On the technician PC, start Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).
segment.target: On the technician PC, start Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).

segment.source: Click FileNew Project.
segment.target: Click FileNew Project.

segment.source: Enter a project name and description, and then click Next
segment.target: Enter a project name and description, and then click Next

segment.source: In the Select project workflow step, select the Provisioning Package option, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Select project workflow step, select the Provisioning Package option, and then click Next.

segment.source: In the Choose which settings to view and configure step, select the Common to all Windows editions option, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Choose which settings to view and configure step, select the Common to all Windows editions option, and then click Next.

segment.source: In the Import a provisioning package (optional) step, click Finish to create the new project.
segment.target: In the Import a provisioning package (optional) step, click Finish to create the new project.

segment.source: Use the Available customizations pane to add settings and specify the defaults which should be restored during recovery.
segment.target: Use the Available customizations pane to add settings and specify the defaults which should be restored during recovery.

segment.source: The settings will appear in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The settings will appear in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: Click ExportProvisioning package.
segment.target: Click ExportProvisioning package.

segment.source: In the Describe the provisioning package step, click Next.
segment.target: In the Describe the provisioning package step, click Next.

segment.source: In the Select the security details for the provisioning package step, click Next.
segment.target: In the Select the security details for the provisioning package step, click Next.

segment.source: In the Select where to save the provisioning package step, enter a location to save the package (such as a network share) and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Select where to save the provisioning package step, enter a location to save the package (such as a network share) and then click Next.

segment.source: Click Build to create the provisioning package.
segment.target: Click Build to create the provisioning package.

segment.source: After the provisioning package is created, click Finish.
segment.target: After the provisioning package is created, click Finish.

segment.source: If your customizations include settings specific to editions of Windows 10 for desktop editions, use the following steps to create an unattend.xml which specifies the settings to be restored during recovery:
segment.target: If your customizations include settings specific to editions of Windows 10 for desktop editions, use the following steps to create an unattend.xml which specifies the settings to be restored during recovery:

segment.source: Step 4: Create an unattend file to restore settings (optional)
segment.target: Step 4: Create an unattend file to restore settings (optional)

segment.source: On the technician PC, start Windows System Image Manager.
segment.target: On the technician PC, start Windows System Image Manager.

segment.source: Click FileSelect Windows image.
segment.target: Click FileSelect Windows image.

segment.source: When prompted to create a catalog file, click Yes.
segment.target: When prompted to create a catalog file, click Yes.

segment.source: Use the Windows Image and Answer File panes to add settings to the Specialize or oobeSystem phase (or both), and specify the defaults which should be restored during recovery.
segment.target: Use the Windows Image and Answer File panes to add settings to the Specialize or oobeSystem phase (or both), and specify the defaults which should be restored during recovery.

segment.source: Click ToolValidate Answer File to check for errors.
segment.target: Click ToolValidate Answer File to check for errors.

segment.source: Correct any problem identified.
segment.target: Correct any problem identified.

segment.source: Click FileSave Answer File.
segment.target: Click FileSave Answer File.

segment.source: Enter a location to save the answer file (such as a network share) and then click Save.
segment.target: Enter a location to save the answer file (such as a network share) and then click Save.

segment.source: If you plan to use Push-button reset’s extensibility points, use the following steps to prepare your extensibility scripts and register them using a Push-button reset configuration file.
segment.target: If you plan to use Push-button reset’s extensibility points, use the following steps to prepare your extensibility scripts and register them using a Push-button reset configuration file.

segment.source: Important If you have created an unattend file, you must also create a script to reapply it using the BasicResetAfterImageApply and FactoryResetAfterImageApply extensibility points.
segment.target: Important If you have created an unattend file, you must also create a script to reapply it using the BasicResetAfterImageApply and FactoryResetAfterImageApply extensibility points.

segment.source: Step 5: Prepare push-button reset extensibility scripts (optional)
segment.target: Step 5: Prepare push-button reset extensibility scripts (optional)

segment.source: Create scripts (.cmd) or executables (.exe) to run at the available extensibility points when the Refresh your PC feature runs:
segment.target: Create scripts (.cmd) or executables (.exe) to run at the available extensibility points when the Refresh your PC feature runs:

segment.source: A: At BasicResetBeforeImageApply
segment.target: A: At BasicResetBeforeImageApply

segment.source: B: At BasicResetAfterImageApply
segment.target: B: At BasicResetAfterImageApply

segment.source: Create scripts (.cmd) or executables (.exe) to run at the available extensibility points when the Reset your PC feature runs:
segment.target: Create scripts (.cmd) or executables (.exe) to run at the available extensibility points when the Reset your PC feature runs:

segment.source: C: At FactoryResetAfterDiskFormat
segment.target: C: At FactoryResetAfterDiskFormat

segment.source: D: At FactoryResetAfterImageApply
segment.target: D: At FactoryResetAfterImageApply

segment.source: Save the scripts to a network location, or USB flash drive.
segment.target: Save the scripts to a network location, or USB flash drive.

segment.source: Create a ResetConfig.xml file that specifies the location of the scripts that you created for the four extensibility points.
segment.target: Create a ResetConfig.xml file that specifies the location of the scripts that you created for the four extensibility points.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Important If you use a text editor to author the ResetConfig.xml file, save the document with an .xml file name extension and use UTF-8 encoding.
segment.target: Important If you use a text editor to author the ResetConfig.xml file, save the document with an .xml file name extension and use UTF-8 encoding.

segment.source: Do not use Unicode or ANSI.
segment.target: Do not use Unicode or ANSI.

segment.source: Save the ResetConfig.xml file together with the extensibility scripts that you created.
segment.target: Save the ResetConfig.xml file together with the extensibility scripts that you created.

segment.source: Step 6: Create bare-metal recovery configuration (optional)
segment.target: Step 6: Create bare-metal recovery configuration (optional)

segment.source: To specify the partition layout to be used when users perform bare metal recovery using recovery media created from their PCs, modify resetconfig.xml to include the following elements:
segment.target: To specify the partition layout to be used when users perform bare metal recovery using recovery media created from their PCs, modify resetconfig.xml to include the following elements:

segment.source: MinSize - Specifies the minimum size of the system disk in megabytes (MB).
segment.target: MinSize - Specifies the minimum size of the system disk in megabytes (MB).

segment.source: Recovery process will not proceed if the system disk does not meet this minimum size.
segment.target: Recovery process will not proceed if the system disk does not meet this minimum size.

segment.source: DiskpartScriptPath - Path to Diskpart script relative to install.wim location.
segment.target: DiskpartScriptPath - Path to Diskpart script relative to install.wim location.

segment.source: The script should assume that all existing partitions have been deleted, and the system disk has focus in Diskpart.
segment.target: The script should assume that all existing partitions have been deleted, and the system disk has focus in Diskpart.

segment.source: OSPartition - The partition to which the recovery image should be applied must be specified.
segment.target: OSPartition - The partition to which the recovery image should be applied must be specified.

segment.source: The ESP or active partition must be on the same disk as the OS.
segment.target: The ESP or active partition must be on the same disk as the OS.

segment.source: WindowsREPartition; WindowsREPath – (Optional) The location in which WinRE should be staged.
segment.target: WindowsREPartition; WindowsREPath – (Optional) The location in which WinRE should be staged.

segment.source: The WinRE boot image on the media will be copied and registered with the OS.
segment.target: The WinRE boot image on the media will be copied and registered with the OS.

segment.source: (Same as running “reagentc.exe /setreimage”)
segment.target: (Same as running “reagentc.exe /setreimage”)

segment.source: If partitioning information is not specified in resetconfig.xml, users can still perform bare metal recovery using media they have created.
segment.target: If partitioning information is not specified in resetconfig.xml, users can still perform bare metal recovery using media they have created.

segment.source: However, the default/recommended partition layout for Windows 10 will be used instead.
segment.target: However, the default/recommended partition layout for Windows 10 will be used instead.

segment.source: Step 7: Create a diskpart script for initial deployment
segment.target: Step 7: Create a diskpart script for initial deployment

segment.source: Create a disk partitioning script for initial deployment.
segment.target: Create a disk partitioning script for initial deployment.

segment.source: UEFI example:
segment.target: UEFI example:

segment.source: BIOS example:
segment.target: BIOS example:

segment.source: Name the script CreatePartitions-UEFI or CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt, and save it to a network location, or USB flash drive.
segment.target: Name the script CreatePartitions-UEFI or CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt, and save it to a network location, or USB flash drive.

segment.source: Note: In these Diskpart examples, the partitions are assigned the letters S:, W:, and T: to simplify partition identification.
segment.target: Note: In these Diskpart examples, the partitions are assigned the letters S:, W:, and T: to simplify partition identification.

segment.source: After the PC reboots, Windows PE automatically assigns the letter C: to the Windows partition.
segment.target: After the PC reboots, Windows PE automatically assigns the letter C: to the Windows partition.

segment.source: The other partitions do not receive drive letters.
segment.target: The other partitions do not receive drive letters.

segment.source: Step 8: Create a diskpart script for bare-metal recovery (optional)
segment.target: Step 8: Create a diskpart script for bare-metal recovery (optional)

segment.source: Step 8: Create a diskpart script for bare-metal recovery (optional)
segment.target: Step 8: Create a diskpart script for bare-metal recovery (optional)

segment.source: Create a diskpart script for bare-metal recovery.
segment.target: Create a diskpart script for bare-metal recovery.

segment.source: Important The diskpart script used for bare metal recovery should not include a or command.
segment.target: Important The diskpart script used for bare metal recovery should not include a or command.

segment.source: The system disk will be selected automatically before the diskpart script is processed.
segment.target: The system disk will be selected automatically before the diskpart script is processed.

segment.source: UEFI example:
segment.target: UEFI example:

segment.source: BIOS example:
segment.target: BIOS example:

segment.source: Name the script RecreatePartitions-UEFI.txt or RecreatePartitions-BIOS.txt, and save it to the same network location, or USB flash drive as create partitions.
segment.target: Name the script RecreatePartitions-UEFI.txt or RecreatePartitions-BIOS.txt, and save it to the same network location, or USB flash drive as create partitions.

segment.source: Step 9: Deploy and customize Windows
segment.target: Step 9: Deploy and customize Windows

segment.source: On the destination PC, boot to Windows PE.
segment.target: On the destination PC, boot to Windows PE.

segment.source: At the Windows PE command prompt, run the script to create the recommended hard drive partitions.
segment.target: At the Windows PE command prompt, run the script to create the recommended hard drive partitions.

segment.source: where N:CreatePartition is the location of the file.
segment.target: where N:CreatePartition is the location of the file.

segment.source: Apply the Windows reference image to the Windows partition.
segment.target: Apply the Windows reference image to the Windows partition.

segment.source: Optional: You can also specify the /compact option so that the files written to disk are compressed.
segment.target: Optional: You can also specify the /compact option so that the files written to disk are compressed.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: This is useful if you are deploying Windows onto PCs with limited storage capacity, but is not recommended on PCs with rotational storage devices.
segment.target: This is useful if you are deploying Windows onto PCs with limited storage capacity, but is not recommended on PCs with rotational storage devices.

segment.source: Configure the system partition by using BCDboot.
segment.target: Configure the system partition by using BCDboot.

segment.source: Create a folder in the Windows RE tools partition, and copy your custom Windows RE boot image to it.
segment.target: Create a folder in the Windows RE tools partition, and copy your custom Windows RE boot image to it.

segment.source: where T: is the Windows RE tools partition.
segment.target: where T: is the Windows RE tools partition.

segment.source: Important You must store Winre.wim in RecoveryWindowsRE.
segment.target: Important You must store Winre.wim in RecoveryWindowsRE.

segment.source: Register the Windows RE boot image together with the Windows image.
segment.target: Register the Windows RE boot image together with the Windows image.

segment.source: Use Diskpart to conceal the Windows RE tools (T:) partition from Windows Explorer.
segment.target: Use Diskpart to conceal the Windows RE tools (T:) partition from Windows Explorer.

segment.source: For UEFI-based PCs:
segment.target: For UEFI-based PCs:

segment.source: For BIOS-based PCs:
segment.target: For BIOS-based PCs:

segment.source: Customize the Windows image on the destination PC:
segment.target: Customize the Windows image on the destination PC:

segment.source: Perform offline customizations to the Windows image, such as installing INF-based driver packages specific to the destination PC, installing OS updates and language packs, or provisioning additional Windows apps.
segment.target: Perform offline customizations to the Windows image, such as installing INF-based driver packages specific to the destination PC, installing OS updates and language packs, or provisioning additional Windows apps.

segment.source: Boot the destination PC to audit mode.
segment.target: Boot the destination PC to audit mode.

segment.source: This can be accomplished by using an answer file with the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Reseal | Mode = audit setting, or by first booting the PC to OOBE, and then pressing CTRL+SHIFT+F3.
segment.target: This can be accomplished by using an answer file with the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Reseal | Mode = audit setting, or by first booting the PC to OOBE, and then pressing CTRL+SHIFT+F3.

segment.source: Perform any remaining customizations such as installing applications and device software packages that are specific to the destination PC.
segment.target: Perform any remaining customizations such as installing applications and device software packages that are specific to the destination PC.

segment.source: If you have installed OS updates, clean up the superseded components and mark the updates as permanent so that they will be restored during recovery:
segment.target: If you have installed OS updates, clean up the superseded components and mark the updates as permanent so that they will be restored during recovery:

segment.source: Step 10: Capture and deploy customizations for recovery
segment.target: Step 10: Capture and deploy customizations for recovery

segment.source: Use the ScanState tool to capture the installed customizations into a provisioning package.
segment.target: Use the ScanState tool to capture the installed customizations into a provisioning package.

segment.source: Use the /config option to specify the configuration file you modified in Step 1 earlier in this topic, and save the .ppkg file in the folder C:RecoveryCustomizations.
segment.target: Use the /config option to specify the configuration file you modified in Step 1 earlier in this topic, and save the .ppkg file in the folder C:RecoveryCustomizations.

segment.source: where N: is the location of the ScanState tool installed in Step 1.
segment.target: where N: is the location of the ScanState tool installed in Step 1.

segment.source: If you have used Windows ICD to create additional provisioning packages with customizations which should be restored during recovery, copy the packages to the destination PC.
segment.target: If you have used Windows ICD to create additional provisioning packages with customizations which should be restored during recovery, copy the packages to the destination PC.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: where N: is the location where the additional provisioning packages are located.
segment.target: where N: is the location where the additional provisioning packages are located.

segment.source: Copy any Push-button reset configuration file (resetconfig.xml) and extensibility scripts to the destination PC, and then configure permissions to write/modify them.
segment.target: Copy any Push-button reset configuration file (resetconfig.xml) and extensibility scripts to the destination PC, and then configure permissions to write/modify them.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: where N: is the location where the configuration file and scripts are located.
segment.target: where N: is the location where the configuration file and scripts are located.

segment.source: Restrict the Write/Modify permissions of the customizations, and hide the root folder.
segment.target: Restrict the Write/Modify permissions of the customizations, and hide the root folder.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Use the Sysprep tool to reseal the Windows image without using the /generalize option.
segment.target: Use the Sysprep tool to reseal the Windows image without using the /generalize option.

segment.source: Note Important: You must configure the image that you are shipping to the customer to boot to OOBE.
segment.target: Note Important: You must configure the image that you are shipping to the customer to boot to OOBE.

segment.source: (Optional) To save space, you can also convert your installed Classic Windows applications into file pointers referencing the customizations package.
segment.target: (Optional) To save space, you can also convert your installed Classic Windows applications into file pointers referencing the customizations package.

segment.source: To do so, boot the destination PC to Windows PE and run the following:
segment.target: To do so, boot the destination PC to Windows PE and run the following:

segment.source: Shut down the destination PC for packaging and shipment.
segment.target: Shut down the destination PC for packaging and shipment.

segment.source: When the user starts the PC for the first time, it will boot to OOBE.
segment.target: When the user starts the PC for the first time, it will boot to OOBE.

segment.source: Step 11: Verify your customizations
segment.target: Step 11: Verify your customizations

segment.source: Verify that your customizations are restored after recovery, and that they continue to function by running the Refresh your PC and Reset your PC features from the following entry points:
segment.target: Verify that your customizations are restored after recovery, and that they continue to function by running the Refresh your PC and Reset your PC features from the following entry points:

segment.source: Settings : From the Start Menu, click Settings Update & security Recovery.
segment.target: Settings : From the Start Menu, click Settings Update & security Recovery.

segment.source: Click the Get Started button under Reset this PC and follow the on-screen instructions.
segment.target: Click the Get Started button under Reset this PC and follow the on-screen instructions.

segment.source: Windows RE: From the Choose an option screen in Windows RE, click Troubleshoot Reset this PC and then follow the on-screen instructions
segment.target: Windows RE: From the Choose an option screen in Windows RE, click Troubleshoot Reset this PC and then follow the on-screen instructions

segment.source: Verify that recovery media can be created, and verify its functionality by running the bare metal recovery feature:
segment.target: Verify that recovery media can be created, and verify its functionality by running the bare metal recovery feature:

segment.source: Launch Create a recovery drive from Control Panel.
segment.target: Launch Create a recovery drive from Control Panel.

segment.source: Follow the on-screen instructions to create the USB recovery drive.
segment.target: Follow the on-screen instructions to create the USB recovery drive.

segment.source: Boot the PC from the USB recovery drive
segment.target: Boot the PC from the USB recovery drive

segment.source: From the Choose an option screen, click Troubleshoot
segment.target: From the Choose an option screen, click Troubleshoot

segment.source: Click Recover from a drive and then follow the on-screen instructions
segment.target: Click Recover from a drive and then follow the on-screen instructions

segment.source: Note The Push-button reset UI has been redesigned in Windows 10.
segment.target: Note The Push-button reset UI has been redesigned in Windows 10.

segment.source: The Keep my files option in the UI now corresponds to the Refresh your PC feature, whereas the Remove everything option corresponds to the Reset your PC feature.
segment.target: The Keep my files option in the UI now corresponds to the Refresh your PC feature, whereas the Remove everything option corresponds to the Reset your PC feature.

segment.source: Deploy push-button reset features using ScanState
segment.target: Deploy push-button reset features using ScanState
